[Lakhon Khon](/wiki/Khon) - Fon - Hun krabok - [Lakhon Nai](/wiki/Lakhon_nai) - [Lakhon Chatri](/wiki/Lakhon_chatri) - [Lakhon Nok](/wiki/Lakhon_nok) - [Likay](/wiki/Likay) - [Manora](/wiki/Menora_(dance)) - [Ma yong](/wiki/Mak_yong) - [Mor lam](/wiki/Mor_lam) - [Ram wong](/wiki/Romvong) - Ram Thai - Rabam - [Kingkara](/wiki/Peacock_dance) Vietnam - [Nhã nhạc](/wiki/Nh%C3%A3_nh%E1%BA%A1c) - v - t - e **Mak Inang** ([Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_script): **مق عناڠ**) is a traditional [Malay](/wiki/Malay_people) dance that originated from the time of [Malacca Sultanate](/wiki/Malacca_Sultanate). The dance is accompanied by a unique music which is believed to have been composed by the order of [Sultan Mahmud Shah](/wiki/Sultan_Mahmud_Shah) of Malacca. In the past, both song and dance were taught to the *Inang* of the palace ("singer dancers") for them to perform it during royal functions. The dance’s movements and its music are so graceful and have all the qualities for court performances. Mak Inang dance is also known as **Si Kembang Cina**, reflecting the existence of Chinese influence in its music. Nowadays, the dance is refined and called with its modern name "Inang", and usually performed in social functions like wedding receptions. This dance-related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e This [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia)-related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Mak Inang
